Fundamentals of Sumi-e
The foundation of sumi-e upon which you can start to learn is the preparation of choboku. This means to create three shades of ink inside the brush.
Every time you want to paint a brush stroke, you have to make the choboku first.
Let\'s go through the five step you need to learn to make choboku.
The First Step
At the beginning you have to know which tools are essential for sumi-e. They are called the Four Treasures: ink stick (墨 sumi), ink stone (硯 suzuri), brush (筆 fude) and paper (和紙 washi).
Sumi is made mainly of soot and animal glue, sometimes with incense or medicinal scents added.
Suzuri is a stone mortar for the grinding and containment of ink.
Washi is commonly made using fibers from cotton, hemp, mulberry and various other plants.

The brushes come in various shapes and sizes, and are usually made using animal hair for the bristles. Typical animal hair may come from goats, sheep, horse-hair, etc. They can be divided into three basic types: brown hair, white hair and mixed hair.
The Second Step

To make ink from the sumi, you have to apply some water onto the suzuri and then gradually rub the inkstick on it. You have to continue the process (eventually adding some water) until the water become dark enough.
Hit the button continue and try it.
Rub the inkstick on the suzuri to prepare sumi.
The Third Step
Now it\'s time to dilute ink to create the light color. You have to fill up the brush with water and then drain it into a dish. After you have to add a little bit of sumi and mix it.
Hit the button continue and try it.
Take at first the water and add it to the dish, then add the ink.
The Fourth Step

Now you have to create the middle color. You have the light color in the brush and you have to mix a little bit of pure sumi. Blend it carefully in a clean dish and you will have a beautiful shade. However pay attention to not dive the brush another time in the water or in the diluted sumi.
Hit the button continue and try it.
Take the ink from the suzuri and then mix the color in the dish.
The Fifth Step
Finally you have to add a little bit of sumi on the brush tip. You can take it from the suzuri and then squash lightly the brush tip on the border of the dish to blend a bit the color.
Hit the button continue and try it.
Take the ink from the suzuri and then press on the border of the dish.
Your progress:
The first kanji (墨) is read \"sumi\" and means ink. It is composed by the kanji black ("黑") and soil ("土") due to the earthly origins of the dark soot used in its production.
The second kanji (絵) is read \"e\" and means painting. It is composed by the kanji black ("黑") and soil ("土") due to the earthly origins of the dark soot used in its production.

Sumi-e uses only black ink in various concentrations. It\'s the art to make beautiful masterpiece with black, white and all the infinite shades between them. Sometimes a little bit of color is added (for example red).

The goal of sumi-e is not simply to reproduce the appearance of the subject, but to capture its spirit. To paint a flower, there is no need to perfectly match its petals and colors, but it is essential to convey its liveliness and fragrance. It\'s an art that captures the unseen.
